We wanted to provide you an update on where we are for the start of school on August 31st.

We are planning for two different starts: the Blended Learning Option of an A-B group of two days in-person and 3 days in remote learning. There is also a complete remote learning option for students wanting to stay home. We are also planning for 100% remote learning for all students..

We have committees in place that are considering: student learning options, emotional health and the physical health environment as described in the Michigan Roadmap to a Safe Return to School . If we do not feel that we can create a safe in-person environment for your child, we will use committee recommendations and Board guidance to start the school year in a remote learning mode.

We will continue to provide the Board and you updates. We will finalize the direction in the next week.

William L. DeFrance

text:
Dear Greyhound Families,

It is with great joy that we are going to be able to assist families who receive reduced price meals with a free meal instead. What does this mean? If you fill out a lunch application during the 2019-2020 school year and are approved for what is normally a reduced meal price, you will now receive it free. This will be provided through the food service budget.

Please also remember that all students district wide are able to receive a free breakfast regardless of their financial status.

All meals at Greyhound Central are free, breakfast and lunch

Please direct questions to the food service department at 663-4280

If you have not filled out an application yet and wish to do so, please go to www.lunchapp.com

Linda Vainner
Food Service Director

Good Morning,

In recent weeks there have been reported cases of Eastern Equine Encephalitis (EEE) across Southwest Michigan. There have been several reports in the media, including a recent statement from the Michigan Department of Health Services (MDHHS). Eastern Equine Encephalitis is a serious, insect borne virus that can have serious health consequences, including death. It is important that we take this seriously and follow precautions set forth by Eaton-Barry Health Department to prevent Eastern Equine Encephalitis.

Barry-Eaton Health Department has released a list of suggestions for community members and school officials to help protect themselves, which we sent out last week. …
